Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Reconstructing Interplanetary Coronal Mass Ejection Evolution Using In-Situ Filament Plasma
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of this 3-year SHINE project is to improve present understanding of the heating and acceleration of Coronal Mass Ejections (CMEs) by examining the physics of interplanetary CME (ICME) evolution, especially as it relates to the filament material and its reflection of the energization of the ejecta. In-situ data and new analysis techniques will both be employed to measure the low charge states of heavy ions for the first time, revealing previously undetected ICME core material. The science objectives aimed with this project are highly relevant to topics that are central to the SHINE community. A fundamental part of the research work integrates the expertise of young scientists at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor with the professional training of seasoned researchers. In addition to providing the community with a comprehensive list of in-situ observations of cold ICMEs, this work will also provide a thermal history of the plasma involved. Future models by the community will be constrained and improved by these plasma results. By including researchers at the undergraduate level in several of the data analysis tasks, this work will also act as a tool to educate and give experience to the rising generation. The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.


The comprehensive survey to result from this SHINE project will relate cold ICME material in the heliosphere to the eruption process at the Sun through two main objectives: (i) determine the prevalence of filament material within ICMEs; and, (ii) determine the physical properties of the CME plasma during the eruption process that are responsible for either preserving or obliterating filament material on its way from the corona into the Heliosphere. The Michigan Ionization Code (MIC) will be used to predict charge state evolution in the filament in order to: (i) investigate the formation of higher charge states and the survival of low charge state ions during the eruption process; and, (ii) reconstruct the energetics of erupting filaments, including the temperature, density, and velocity evolution of the plasma from launch to the freeze-in point. Thus, the outcome of this project is expected to be of great value to the solar-heliospheric community, and SHINE in particular.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate the presence, evolution, and properties of cold plasma embedded in Interplanetary Coronal Mass Ejections (ICMEs). This plasma, identified in in-situ measurement by the presence of low-ionization species, is critically important for the overall energetics of the ICME and for its evolution. Remote sensing observations have revealed that around 70% of CMEs leaving the Sun include cold prominence material that can be considered the seed material for ICME cold plasma; still, only 4% of all ICMEs show signatures of such a cold plasma, leaving the question open as to the fate of the erupting prominence material. The question is: has this cold material been further ionized in interplanetary space before reaching the instrument, or has it become so fragmented that its likelihood to hit the instrument is decreased?

 

In our project, we have first identified an additional process that contributes to the continued ionization of cold ICME material: photoionization from solar EUV and X-ray radiation, which increases the total ionization rate of key elements such as C, N, and O. We have studied the effects of this process on ICME plasma ionization.

 

We have also developed new diagnostic techniques to determine the properties of cold ICME material and their time evolution using remote sensing observations. These techniques, utilizing either cold plasma absorption properties, or direct detection of cold ICME plasma with ground-based observatories, allow for the first time continuous measurement of the evolution of the properties and ionization status of erupting prominences near the Sun, in the height range which is most critical to their final charge state composition.

 

We have then applied these techniques to Extreme-Ultraviolet observations of an erupting prominence as it was being ejected from the solar atmosphere, and measured its thermal properties and energetics as a function of time for the first time. Results showed that the erupting prominence plasma temperature was constant, meaning that while this plasma was being heated, the energy it received was not enough to increase its temperature and so its ionization stage remained constant. This means that either this plasma was going to be heated at much larger distances than anticipated (beyond the field of view of the instrument), or it was too filamentary to be detected in-situ.

 

We also carried out extensive empirical modeling of ICME plasma evolution to determine, from in-situ charge state composition measurements, the evolution of the plasma electron density (N) and temperature (T), and speed (V), from the Sun all the way to the instrument (near Earth). By iteratively modifying initial curves of T, N and V as a function of distance from the Sun, we calculated the evolution with distance of the charge state distribution and compared it to measurements, and kept modifying the initial curves until satisfactory agreement was reached. The best results were obtained by assuming that the ICME plasma was made of 4 components (only one of which consisted of the erupting prominence/cold ICME material); 2 of them were considerably heated as the CME progressed, and one of them was made of coronal material being pushed away by the CME. Results also showed that the erupting prominence was being heated up to long distances, but its charge state distribution still remained fairly low, thus indicating that low-ionization material survived the ICME eruption and could in principle be detected in situ. This modeling allowed us also to determine the distribution of the energy in all four plasmas, identify where energy was deposited into each plasma component, and at what height was the plasma accelerated.

 

As a final result, our empirical modeling allowed us to answer the question underlying the whole project: cold ICME plasma does survive the eruption and the journey from the Sun to the Earth, but its filamentary structure makes its detection by in-situ instrumentation less likely.
